origination.corpname: United Church of Christ. Michigan Conference.

did.unittitle: United Church of Christ. Michigan Conference records 1840-2013
did.abstract: The Michigan Conference of the United Church of Christ was formed from the merger of the Michigan Conference of the Congregational Church and the Michigan-Indiana Synod of the Evangelical and Reformed Church. The record group includes retired records of individual associations, conferences, and local churches. Also included are files on churches and pastors within the Conference.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The records are on deposit from the Michigan Conference (donor no. 4591). The records of the Ann Arbor Regional Women's Guild came from Mrs. Elvira Vogel (donor no. 7908).

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is not held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, United Church of Christ. Michigan Conference records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The United Church of Christ was formed from the merger in 1957 of the Congregational Christian Church and the Evangelical and Reformed Church. Subsequently, on April 17, 1963, the Michigan Congregational Conference and the Michigan-Indiana Synod of the Evangelical and Reformed Church merged to form the Michigan Conference of the United Church of Christ.

The Congregational churches of Michigan were organized into a State Association on October 11, 1842. Previously, in May 1840, the Eastern Association and Conference had been organized for the southeastern portion of the state; in 1841, the Marshall Conference (later Olivet Conference) was established, followed by the Jackson Conference in May 1842. Church leaders at the time believed that if the church was ever to become strong and efficient in the state it would need a state-wide association. The formal name of the new organization was the General Association of the Congregational Ministers and Churches of Michigan.

As of 2014, the United Church of Christ Michigan Conference consisted of the following six associations: Covenant, Detroit Metropolitan, Eastern, GrandWest, Southwest, and United Northern. The collection contains records from each of these associations.

Each of these individual associations are the product of mergers between smaller associations of churches. The Covenant Association consists of mergers between several associations. The Jackson Association (organized in 1842) merged with the Ann Arbor Region, Evangelical and Reformed Churches in 1964 to become the Ann Arbor-Jackson Association. In 1978, the Ann Arbor-Jackson Association merged with the Central Association (organized in 1845) to become the Covenant Association.
In 1993, the Grand Rapids Association and the West Michigan Association merged to form the GrandWest Association.

scopecontent.p: This record group is comprised primarily of records of the associations and conferences that make up the United Church of Christ Michigan Conference. The records document the mergers between smaller conferences to make the larger ones of today. These records are largely made up of correspondence, minutes, agendas, conference materials, and programming information.

Besides records of the individual associations and conferences, the collection also contains an extensive amount of records from individual churches, which can be found in the "Records from individual churches" and the "Church files" series. Because their relationship to each other is unknown, these series were not combined. The "Church files" series are records that may have been stored by the Michigan Conference rather than the individual churches. The "Records from individual churches" concerns materials that belonged to the individual churches. Whether these churches belonged to the smaller associations that make up the Michigan Conference is unknown. Therefore, they were kept separate. More information on these series can be found in the individual series' description below.

The record group has been arranged into the following series: Michigan Conference; Associations and conferences; Woman's Home Missionary Union and related; Records from individual churches; Annual Meetings of Michigan Congregational Conference and of the United Church of Christ; Evangelical and Reformed Church; Church files; Photographs; Ministerial files; and Student ministry.

scopecontent.p: The Michigan Conference series (2 linear feet) contains records of the Michigan Conference. There is a record book dating from 1855 that contains the constitution and proceedings of the annual session. There are also minutes of the Executive Committee and Board of Trustees of the Michigan Congregational Conference between 1890 and 1963. This series also contains minutes from of the Property Management and Development committee. It contains newsletters and newspapers that were published by the Michigan Conference. There are also publications from other churches, which includes a cookbook and a history of the First Congregational Church of Battle Creek. Finally, there is a VHS tape by St. Paul United Church of Christ that records their closing service on April 19, 1998.

odd.p: (include constitution and proceedings of annual session)

Board of Trustees of the General Association of Congregational Churches and Ministers, Committee on Home Missions

Make Ahead Favorites: Foods with a Flair, Huron Shores Business and Professional Women's Club
VHS tape, St. Paul United Church of Christ, Closing Service: Remembrance and Appreciation 1998

scopecontent.p: The Associations and conferences series (8 linear feet) contains the records of the associations and conferences that make up the Michigan Conference. Some of these associations and conferences do not currently exist. Other associations, such as the Covenant Association, are made up of several associations that merged. In this case, the individual associations make up a group within that association. The journals within the series contains meeting minutes, reports, and information about the association. Record books contain similar information. Meeting records contain meeting minutes and agendas. The records were kept in the original order of the creator. Therefore, in some instances council and association minutes are contained within the same folder (indicated by "council/association minutes"). The series also contains a scrapbook of the Boulevard Congregational Church (Box 20), which contains pictures, bulletins, and newsletters of the church. Committee papers include correspondence, meeting minutes, and meeting agendas. In addition, the series contains annual reports and newsletters.

scopecontent.p: The Woman's Home Missionary Union and related series (1 linear foot) contains records of the Woman's Home Missionary Union and related women's organizations. Record books contain information such as minutes and committee information. The series also includes financial ledgers.

did.unittitle: Record book 1873-1890 include constitution and reports from local missionary societies
Minutes 1936-1943 of the Women's Department of the Executive Board
Minutes 1847-1880 of the First Congregational Ladies Sewing Society of Jackson
Woman's Foreign Missionary Society, Kalamazoo Association
Financial ledger 1947-1957 of the Women's Fellowship, Kalamazoo Association
Woman's Missionary Society of the Congregational Church of Hancock, Michigan

scopecontent.p: The Records from individual churches series (3 linear feet and 1 outsize folder) contains items from individual churches that were donated separately from their associated conference. In Box 4, there is a scrapbook from the First Congregational Church of Stanton. There are also journals and record books from individual churches that contain meeting minutes, agendas, and by-laws. In addition, there is about one linear foot of records from the Nativity United Church of Christ in Livonia, Michigan. A significant portion of their records consists of church bulletins from their services between the years 2000 and 2011. There are two histories of the church included within the collection that were written in 1986 and 2013. Finally, there are display folders contained within an outsize folder that displays photographs and information of the congregation's history.

The series also contains minutes of the Grand Rapids Association of Congregational Ministers and Wives from 1910-1957. In addition, the series contains the Schmid letters, which were written by a pioneer German missionary. There are also histories of Michigan Congregational Churches. The biographical sketches are brief essays on various early ministers in Michigan. The miscellaneous folder contains volume one of The History of Congregational Churches in Maine by Calvin Clark. It also includes a prayer, reports, and pamphlets.

scopecontent.p: The Annual Meetings of the Michigan Congregational Conference and of the United Church of Christ series (0.5 linear feet) contains meeting records, including minutes and agendas, of the annual meetings of the Michigan Congregational Conference from 1910-1963. It also contains meeting minutes and agendas from the annual meetings of the United Church of Christ (which formed from the Michigan Congregational Conference) between 1964-1967 and 1976.

2nd annual meeting of the United Church of Christ 1965
3rd annual meeting of the United Church of Christ 1966

scopecontent.p: The Evangelical and Reformed Church series (1.5 linear feet) contains minutes of the Fort Wayne Classis Evangelical and Reformed Church. It also contains newsletters and acts/proceedings of the Michigan-Indiana Synod of the Evangelical and Reformed Church. The series includes information from the following women's organizations: Ann Arbor Regional Women's Guild, Michigan-Indiana Synodical Women's Guild, and the Women's Guild of the Evangelical and Reformed Church. Each section contains items such as meeting minutes, newsletters, by-laws, and annual reports. The Michigan-Indiana Synodical Women's Guild section also contains directories between the years of 1942-1958. The miscellaneous folder in the Women's Guild of the Evangelical and Reformed Church contains reports, a photograph, meeting minutes, and correspondence.

did.unittitle: Minutes 1931-1940 of the Fort Wayne (Indiana) Classis Evangelical and Reformed church
Acts and Proceedings of the Michigan-Indiana Synod of the Evangelical and Reformed Church 1944-1963
Synod News 1956-1962 [newsletter of the Michigan-Indiana Synod of the Evangelical and Reformed Church]
Evangelical and Reformed Church printed material
Ann Arbor Regional Women's Guild (name of the organization varies)
Women's Guild of the Evangelical and Reformed Church (United Church of Christ)

scopecontent.p: The Church files series (4.5 linear feet) is arranged alphabetically by city and are primarily Congregational. These records concern the establishment of churches in these cities and contain items such as correspondence and minutes. They may be files about the churches that were held by the United Church of Christ Michigan Conference, rather than by the churches themselves.

did.unittitle: Dearborn St. James Evangelical and Reformed Church
Detroit. Peace United Church of Christ Evangelical and Reformed
Detroit. St. John's Evangelical and Reformed Church
Dexter. St. Andrews United Church of Christ
Farmington. Salem United Church of Christ
Grosse Pointe. Grace United Church of Christ
Livonia. Nativity United Church of Christ
Royal Oak. Emmanuel-Bethel United Church of Christ
Watervliet, St. Paul's United Church of Christ

scopecontent.p: The Photographs, 1890s-1900s series (0.5 linear feet) contains photos of various Congregational church buildings, parsonages, and homes, many from Upper Peninsula communities in the period of 1890s and 1900s. There are also photographs and portraits (1930s-1950s) of Congregational Church ministers.

The Ministerial files series (4.5 linear feet) is arranged alphabetically by clergyman. The clergymen were either pastors of Congregational or Evangelical and Reformed churches which later joined the Michigan Conference of the United Church of Christ, or pastors of churches which refused to merge into the Michigan Conference. The files contain biographical information and correspondence between the Conference and the individual pastors.

The Student ministry series (0.5 linear feet) includes information on student ministries in cities across Michigan. The bulk of the files contain correspondence and reports concerning student affairs during the 1940s and 1950s. Finally, the series contains a description of the University of Michigan's North Campus Development project and correspondence.
